text: What's up everybody? Ableton has just announced a substantial update to live, bringing it to version 10.1.

and we've had a chance to put it through its paces.

The first example I'm going to show you is how delay can be used to treat a lead vocal.
Here's what the vocal sounds like raw on solo.
And in the mix.
The original sample is totally dry.
It obviously doesn't have a place in the mix and it stands out.
I know a lot of producers would reflexively reach for a reverb here, but when mixing vocals,
delay can actually be a really great alternative.
That said, you need to be treading carefully here and be strategic because if done wrong,
it can totally wash out your vocal.
Unless you're going for that far away, weird sounding kind of spacey vocal treatment, you
have to mix it tactfully.
Let's listen to the treatment I've done with delay here.
You guys digging this or what?
You can hear it's adding a sense of space and helping her to blend in with the mix while
still keeping that upfront and intimate sound that lead vocal should have.
We're getting this result partially by automating the feedback.
When the vocals in, the feedback is set to zero, meaning it's only going to give you
one echo.
Because the delay time is synced to the beat, this means the echo is two sixteenth notes
or an eighth note behind the dry signal.
This gives us a nice little BPM synced rhythmic single delay.
Then when the vocal finishes, we can see that the feedback is automated up, giving it a
nice long kind of spacey tail.
The filters also playing a big role here.
It's removing the lows and highs to give lots of space to the air range of the vocal and
the sub range of the 808 beneath it.
The frequency set pretty low at 475 Hertz because as an engineer, I prefer quite dark
sounding ambience.
As a final touch, it's possible to add some nice stereo width to this vocal with delay.
The original samples totally mono, so if we wanted a wider sounding treatment, we could
simply change the offset parameters of the left and the right delay channels in opposite
directions.
In this case, I've set up a macro to do just that.
Check it out.
If you guys are digging this so far, I'll invite you to join the community by subscribing
to our channel.
Also, smash that notification spell if you want to get the heads up on all the things
right as we post them.
In this example, we're going to use delay for sound design rather than mixing duties.
There are four instances of it working in different ways on these drums to make them
sound metallic and spacey.
Here's what we've got.
With the first snare, we're using an unsynced delay time in milliseconds to give fairly
quick repeats with feedback turned up.
Then the bandpass filter is isolating the frequencies we want to be heard ringing out.
A heavy duty parallel compressor in the group is helping the tail to really stand out here.
Looking at the second snare, we've got a similar setup but now with some automation.
The mode is set to repitch and we're automating the unsynced decay time from pretty short
to a little longer.
This will make the delay's tail lower in pitch.
The filter frequency is also being automated to accentuate this.
Finally, we've got a very metallic sounding delay on the drum loop.
This one's also set to unsynced time and the macro knob is shortening the decay time
in repitch mode, giving a sense of increasing pitch while introducing a distinct ringing tone.
Note how the feedback and wet dry increases while the decay time decreases.
This is much more pronounced and full range because the filter isn't being used to tame
things up.
It's a really in-your-face sounding effect.
This audio effect rack, called the Glitch Bitch, is something I built years ago to easily
mangled sounds and tracks in DJ sets or in songs that I'm producing.

I wanted you guys to have this so I've included it as a free download for you in the link

Mess about with it and have some fun.

The rest of the effects are just for some extra detail.
So the Freeze function in the new Delay will grab what's currently in the buffer and repeat
it indefinitely.
The trick is to get the right sample into the buffer.
Big Jer, one of the Ableton certified trainers on our team here at Warp Academy, built this
drop, and I really liked the horns he used in the stack group, so I grabbed the downbeat
from them.
In my own tunes, I really like using pieces of the song itself to make effects like risers,
fallers, impacts, and reverse reverbs.
I find it helps everything to gel together.
Looking at the automation, I played the horns clip, then triggered the Freeze function,
which is mapped using a Macro right after.
Then I turned the Freeze function off again in the gap just before the drop.
Then I let the automation targeting Macro 1 do all the work.
The reason I like using a Macro for this inside of a rack is that it makes it really easy
to get finer resolution on the movements you want.
And you can also easily make edits afterwards without fussing about with the automation
envelope itself.
If you open the Macro mappings browser, you can see all the stuff I have mapped to it.
The rising pitch sound is really the central thing though, and that's coming from this
right here.
You can see the unsynced time is being reduced from 375 to 10 milliseconds.
With the delay and repitch mode, that's what's giving it this nice smooth pitch increase.
One thing to note is that you need to be in a free rate here, versus synced, so the delay
time can move smoothly rather than jumping to the next closest 16th note in sync time.
